text: Wanted to just talk about this comment
here on my latest video. A lot of people
were commenting that level one charging
is totally doable. And I think if you
have a very short commute and a very
efficient EV, that might be true. And
I've tried this. So I know in terms of
my lifestyle living in a residential
area in San Diego and taking my kids to
school in the back and all that that
during the week I can totally get by
with level one charging, which is great.
But then on the weekends we want to go
to the beach, we want to go out to a
different part of town, we want to
explore and that's where you sort of
lose it, you know. So if you have a long
commute or if you live in a place that
you know you explore and drive around a
lot during the week you might be fine
but then on the weekends is where you're
going to lose it and then unfortunately
you're not going to be able to get that
range back. That's really the challenge
as far as I see is that you'll
eventually have to hit a public charger
and maybe that's fine. Maybe that's fine
for you. I found it to be too cumbersome
considering installing a level two
charger depending on your situation can
be pretty reasonable. So that's my
little feedback on that. I'll put a link
down to that video if you want to see
when I did a this test of just using
public chargers using my Tesla Model 3
all the way back in gez I think 2018
